headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: U.S. Condemns Attacks in West Bank; Black Business Owners of MAGA Merchandise Speak to CNN; Kevin Sears is Interviewed about Real Estate Rules Changes. Aired 9:30-10a ET

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: But the big point I'll make very quickly here, the Federal Reserve is what controls inflation. Keeping that independent is essential, Sara. We've talked about it before. Trump's talked about having a say. Kamala said, look, she'll leave them independent. Right answer.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right. When it comes to Social Security, what's been the messaging there?

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: So, this is the Trump campaign now. And they've said, look, people who receive Social Security should not pay taxes on it. Around 67 million people in this country get those Social Security benefits. Around 40 percent pay taxes. So, we are talking about a lot of people.Just take a look at how it works. I'll just give you a sense. If you earn below $25,000 as an individual, you don't pay taxes at all. But if you do earn above that, then up to 50 percent of those benefits are taxable. And, of course, it's a bit more for joint people. Removing that, according to the tax policy center, could save people around $550. That sounds great. The problem is, how do you pay for it? If Donald Trump is not talking about perhaps raising taxes on high earners, then perhaps you have to start dipping into some of these Social Security funds. And we know they're already under pressure. The fear is that they're going to run out in -- around ten years' time unless something changes on that front. So -- so that would be a sort of flag to raise there. It's also going to significantly add to the deficit as well. I'm not sure how much we care about these things, but we should care about these things. Yes, that's the problem with the funds, of course, that you can see on your screen there. SIDNER: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: And it would be a huge problem because that could mean benefit cuts in the future.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes, Social Security is usually the third rail when talking about it. Although, if you're cutting taxes, that's a different thing.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: So (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Housing, a huge issue. People talk about this all the time. What's the plan?

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, let's understand the problem very quickly. Supply and demand. We don't have enough houses, first and foremost. Mortgage rates are high, so people are afraid of buying a new house or moving house because they can't get a cheap enough mortgage. That will help as mortgage rates come down.But if people can't even get on the housing ladder, it pushes rents up too. So, that's in a nutshell the crisis. Kamala Harris coming out with a whole host of plans. The most important point I think and to get to the heart of the issue is increasing the amount of houses out there. So, federal resources to build three million new housing units, check. We like the idea of that. Some support for first-time homebuyers is coming in too. Look, Trump has also talked about expanding land available in order to build more houses, which the important point is, there's some gray area over a big fund that she's talking about. But this is really taking a leap and expanding what Biden announced earlier, and adding to it. And it helps. It's not a fix all. We're lacking 300,000 construction workers. So, let's find the workers to build those houses too, Sara.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes, we are expecting to hear Kamala Harris' full throated idea on how to deal with the economy for the first time today.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: So, a lot of people will be watching for that.Julia Chatterley, thank you so much. Appreciate you. Kate.

utterances.speaker: KATE BOLDUAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Some breaking news overnight. The White House now condemning an attack by Israeli settlers on a Palestinian village in the occupied West Bank. A spokesperson for the White House National Security Council saying this, "attacks by violent settlers against Palestinian civilians in the West Bank are unacceptable and must stop."CNN's Nic Robertson joins us now live in the West Bank. Nic, what are you seeing?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's exactly right. That context around this is also so important.Nic, thank you very much for your reporting. Sara.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump and his campaign have been making a strong push to try and win over black voters this election. They're seeing some success. What are those voters saying?CNN's Elle Reeve went to Virginia to find out. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) JO ANNE PRICE, RUNS A MAGA-THEMED STORE: Every woman ought to have one of these. It's one of those things that when people see one, then they want one. Same thing with the confederate hat. You know why? Because people don't think you have the nerve to do it. ELLE REEVE, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice over): Jo Anne Price runs a Trump store in Christiansburg, Virginia.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: When Joe Biden announced he wouldn't run for president again, was there any part of you who felt a pull to vote for Harris?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: No, absolutely not.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Why not?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: I would not vote for either one of them. I would not vote Democrat ticket. No way.This is a white privilege card. And this is just a play -- it just says, this card trumps everything and it gives the bearer happiness and success because of the color of their skin.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: And who buys that?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: White people.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: It's funny.

utterances.speaker: SEBRIAM VANNOY, TRUMP SUPPORTER
utterances.sentences: And then when you give it to a state trooper, they let you go. And don't write you a ticket.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: You think so?

utterances.speaker: VANNOY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I've experienced it.

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Wait, really?

utterances.speaker: VANNOY
utterances.sentences: Yes. And he said, OK. He laughed at it and he gave it back to me and did not write me a ticket. REEVE (voice over)

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: It's humorous to us, you know, it really is. It's humerus to the average American I here.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: You know --

utterances.speaker: VANNOY
utterances.sentences: Chances are two to one he was a Republican too.REEVE (voice over): Trump has been working to appeal to black voters and polls showed some success when Biden was still in the race, but have since gone down.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: The Trump campaign this year has made a big effort to reach out to black voters. What do you think of their efforts?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: I think their efforts are succeeding tremendously. All the things that have happened to President Trump, the attacks on him, have done nothing more than strengthen black people's connection to him because now he's someone who is the target of a struggle and they have always been -- felt that they've been a target.I did prison ministries for five years, so, you know, if you're a convicted felon and then somebody else is a convicted felon, there's a camaraderie there. REEVE (voice over): Donald Trump attacked Kamala Harris, questioning her racial identity. She's black. DONALD TRUMP (R), FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT AND 2024 PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: She was only promoting Indian heritage. I didn't know she was black until a number of years ago when she happened to turn black. And now she wants to be known as black. REEVE (voice over): He's acknowledged his commentary has provoked mixed reactions. Price is just one person, and not a swing voter. But we were curious what she made of his comments given that she's a black woman and fervent Trump supporter and former local Republican Party chair.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: How do you make sense of how Trump talks about Vice President Kamala Harris, that he sort of suggested he doesn't understand her biracial background. That first she was Indian and then she was black. What do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: I don't understand it either. She's Indian and she's Jamaican.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: Is she black?

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: I mean, do you not think she's black?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: Is he? Was she born here?

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Were her parents citizens? No.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: OK. But we have birthright citizenship in America.

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Do you --

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: We call -- we call that anchor.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: People can immigrate here and not be citizens but have green cards and work permits.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: How do you reconcile that? Like, you have a history of blended families in your family.

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh. Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: How do you reconcile that with Trump seeming to not understand how Kamala Harris could have a blended family herself?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: Herself? She could have a blended family. What I'm saying is, is his comments about that, I think he's making a point. And, you know, I'm not -- I'm not so disturbed by that.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: But what is the point he's making?

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: The point he's making simply is, is that she is not a black, black person.REEVE (voice over): There were some mixed views on the idea of a woman president.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: What do you think about Kamala Harris?

utterances.speaker: VANNOY
utterances.sentences: Kamala Harris, may I say this, and hopefully that you ladies won't get offended, but because of what happened in the Garden of Eden, there will never be an elected woman, whether she's black or white, that will occupy the White House that God would ever stand behind.

utterances.speaker: MERRIE TURNER, PASTOR WHO BACKS TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure America's quite ready for female leadership. It would be wonderful to have a female president if and when one arises that has conservative values that are going to lead the nation in prosperity.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Did Joe Biden dropping out change your view of the election at all?JOE SHANNON, OBAMA-TO-TRUMP VOTER: Oh, it surely did. I think she's going to be worse than Joe. I just don't think she has the experience. I think she was only chosen because she was a woman.

utterances.speaker: PRICE
utterances.sentences: He has been mocked, scrutinized, slandered, dragged into court. This man is still standing. And he's standing strong because he knows that he was chosen. He's our David.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: So, Ms. Price and her customers, they were joking a lot about those items in the store. But that last image of Trump walking on water next to Jesus Christ, they're very serious about it. They see him as guided by God, even if he's an imperfect vessel for that mission. And I think that helps explain why they're able to brush off his inflammatory comments.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: OK. Starting tomorrow, major new rules on buying and selling a home go into effect nationwide. It is going to be a seismic shift potentially for homeowners, would-be buyers, and real estate agents. The new rules change how real estate agents get paid, and it's the result of a $418 million settlement between homeowners and the National Association of Realtors.Joining us now, Kevin Sears, the president of the National Association of Realtors. Thank you so much for coming in this morning to kind of talk through this and explain what happened here. First of all, what exactly are these changes?

utterances.speaker: KEVIN SEARS, PRESIDENT, NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF REALTORS
utterances.sentences: Well, good morning, Sara. Thank you for the opportunity.Now, there are two big practice changes that will be occurring by tomorrow's deadline of August 17th. The first has to do more with home sellers in their real estate professional. And the second has to do on the buyer's side. So, first, on the seller's side, not much is going to change when it comes to listing the home. The real estate professional, their agent, broker, their realtor will still meet with them, talk about the listing, what needs to be done to get the house ready for sale. But part of the conversation that will change will be about the commission. Commissions, as long as I've been in business since 1994, and for at least 25 years before that, have always been negotiable. And now we're going to have just a little bit of a different conversation because as a listing agent, I will talk about the fee that I'm looking to get paid and then we will explain to the seller that they have the opportunity to offer cooperating compensation or a commission to the buyer's representative. The seller does not have to do that. But what they need to understand is that they do not offer a commission to the buyer's representative, then there might be some buyers who cannot afford to pay their own feet and they might not view the home. So, we just need to have a robust conversation with the consumer and let them make the decision because ultimately it's the consumer who drives the transaction. We are just there to guide them through what is typically a challenging and difficult process.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I mean the thing --

utterances.speaker: SEARS
utterances.sentences: On the buy side --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: SEARS
utterances.sentences: What buyers can expect -- I'm sorry, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: No, go ahead. On the buyer's side. That's what I was going to ask you about.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right, Kevin Sears, make sure you have those conversations. Thank you so much. Appreciate you.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: That is definitely the takeaway.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Talk through it a lot.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Have the conversation.  Yes, exactly. Before you jump in.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Happy Friday, everyone. Thank you so much for joining us.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Ah.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: So glad.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Your lips to God's ears.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: So right (ph).
